p: Viral lung titers and mouse pathogenicity of the H1 virus construct were compared to those of the parental H1N1 PB2-E627 LPAI virus. As expected ( 15), using an intranasal dose of 10 3 PFU in 50 µl, the H1 PB2-E627 virus induced no pathological changes ( Table 1). In contrast, 10 3 PFU of the H1 virus with the PB2 E627K change was markedly pathogenic in mice, causing rapid weight loss and 100% mortality by day 8 ( n = 5 per group) ( Fig. 1B). This H1 virus was subsequently determined to have a mouse 50% lethal dose (MLD 50) of 1.8 log 10 PFU ( Table 1) ( n = 5 per dose), comparable to the MLD 50 of the fully reconstructed 1918 virus ( 15). In order to exclude that this pathogenic phenotype reflected a strain-specific phenomenon with the HA gene of the H1 virus, a second chimeric H1 virus, expressing the HA from another randomly selected LPAI virus H1 strain (H1b) (see Table S1 in the supplemental material), was rescued. The two H1 HA proteins contained 12 coding differences (4; also data not shown). The second H1 virus (H1b) was equally pathogenic in mice, with an MLD 50 ( Fig. 1C and Table 1) comparable to those of the H1 and 1918 viruses ( 15).
